segments.content: Social dilemmas embody the conflict between social and individual interests. Animals may maintain the same community and social ties, either by collectively coordinating their movements, or by coming back to the same territorial patches where they once settled.

Under fully independent movement models, the position of each individual is independent both of where they were previously and of where other individuals will be. The probability that an individual i n is in place p m is generally defined by p nm.

Cooperation can evolve under sufficiently large v /k in public goods games, irrespective of the number of communities m, their size q (provided it allows them to produce a reward), and how they are connected. decreasing the size of the network has a detrimental effect to cooperation under all public goods dilemmas.

Public goods dilemmas consistently lead to the evolution of cooperation down to lower values of the rewardto-cost ratio when a larger number of smaller communities is considered. This is in contrast with the models under which network topology plays a key role.
